 I 1. BACKGROUND A. RECENT ECONOMIC, POLITICAL AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENTS 1.1 Background. Emerging from 35 years of dictatorship, Paraguay has undergone numerous political and economic changes in its transition to democracy. While the legacy of close to four decades of dictatorial rule is still visible, Paraguay has made important strides in its quest to become a modern, democratic state. Despite poor macroeconomic management in the 1 980s, extreme poverty continues to be lower than in many countries with higher per capita incomes, because income distribution is more equitable than the average for Latin America. Moreover, the new Government has made substantial improvements in macroeconomic management, reducing inflation and public external debt, and increasing foreign reserves. However, despite these improvements, the average annual growth recorded for the 1992-1995 was less than 3.0 percent, the same as the rate of population growth. Stagnating and sometimes declining per capita income threatens the economic well-being attained thus far, and is already resulting in reduced access for social services to the poor, especially in rural areas. A strengthening of health services to underserved populations is central to improving welfare, ensuring more productive and healthy lives and reduced population growth. 1.2 Economic Policy. The Government of Paraguay seeks to create an environment for sustained private sector-led growth. To improve the climate for long-term investment the Government seeks to strengthen financial intermediation, restructure and privatize public sector enterprises, improve transportation infrastructure, and modernize the legal and institutional environment. For the public sector, this means divesting itself of responsibilities more appropriate for the private sector, containing the expansion of public sector expenditures, and improving the management capacity of its institutions in areas where it is to play a supportive role, such as agricultural services, infrastructure and human resource development, enabling Paraguay to remain competitive in MERCOSUR and the broader external economy. In human resource development and agriculture, it seeks to strengthen service delivery capability, leading to improvements in the quantity and quality of services provided. 1.3 Some steps have been taken along these lines, not all of them with the intended consequences. To reduce the public deficit and improve efficiency, the Government is promoting the privatization of some public sector enterprises, where appropriate. It is also taking the necessary steps to decentralize some public services, namely health and education, to the municipalities and departments. And, it has increased social spending. 1.4 The decentralization of government services began in 1989 with the transfer of political power to municipal governments. Although prior to that time municipal governments and councils were elected, mayors were appointed by the central government. Since 1991, mayors have become elected officials. The 1992 Constitution (Article 168) broadens municipal responsibilities to include urban planning, environment, markets, tourism, health, police, traffic management and the supervision of public
 2 transportation. To enable them to fulfill their new role, Article 169 transfers the property tax previously collected by the central govemment to the municipalities. Municipalities are allowed to retain 70 percent of revenues which altogether amount to less than 5 percent of the central Government budget. There are no transfers from higher governmental levels to municipalities. Departments receive 15 percent of the property tax collected by municipalities, a 15-percent share of the value-added tax from the central Government, and a 30-percent share of gambling income. Departmental revenues amount to less than one percent of the central Govemment budget. Thus, the amount of resources transferred has been minimal. Because the operational arrangements to implement the new legal framework have not been specified, the assignment of responsibilities across the three levels of government is unclear, leading to a lack of accountability, duplication of some functions and absence of others. The assignment of responsibilities across the three levels of govemment has not been specified, leading to a lack of accountability, duplication of some functions and absence of others. Moreover, municipalities and departments lack the capability to manage their new responsibilities. 1.5 The Government has also increased expenditures in the social sectors. Although social spending has been historically low in Paraguay, the Government increased public health expenditures from 1.0 to 2.5 percent of GDP from 1989 to 1994. However, most of the increase was absorbed by an increase in public wages and to a lesser extent on capital expenditures. Both of these increased at the expense of materials and supplies. Thus, increased spending did not lead to needed improvements in quantity and quality of services provided. B. POVERTY AND SOCIAL EXPENDITURES 1.6 Paraguay has low levels of poverty relative to other countries in the region. The highest poverty levels are found in the northeastem departments, and some of the peripheral areas surrounding Asunci6n (see Table 1). These include the most rural departments and represent some of the areas where the Government has invested the least in basic services. Due to years of underinvestment in such services, only one-fifth of all rural dwellings have running water, and 16 percent have sanitation. Paved roads are scarce and less than forty percent of households have electricity. Health resources are also more scarce in the North. These departments contain most of Paraguay's indigenous population and many of the new settlements of rural migrants. 1.7 Social Policy. The Constitution assigns the Govemment the responsibility for the provision of social services to lower income groups. In the case of education, the Constitution specifies the proportion of the budget to be earmarked for education. It does not do so for health. But the Govemment's commitment to strengthen health services is evident from the numerous health projects currently under preparation and implementation with the financial assistance of KMl, JICA, UNFPA, USAID, the Spanish Government, the IDB and the Bank (Asunci6n Sewerage Project, Ln. 3842-PA; and Third Water Supply Project Ln, 3519-PA).

Paraguay's cause of death structure characterizes it as being in a mid-epidemiological transition stage, with both infectious diseases and chronic/degenerative diseases among the top five killers. Despite the low overall investment in health, Paraguayans have a relatively favorable health profile. Life expectancy at birth is equal to the regional average and infant mortality is slightly lower than the regional average. Nutritional status is one of the best in the region (see Annex 1, Table 1). Ministry of Health statistics for 1991 report a maternal mortality rate of 152 per 100,000 births. Ministry figures, however, provide only a partial view of the problem as many cases are not reported because they occur in small private clinics or simply because women never reach a health provider. Underreporting is greater when maternal mortality is the result of an induced illegal abortion. Adjusting for underregistration, studies have estimated maternal mortality to be as high as 386 per 100,000 births. The main causes of death are abortion (28 percent of all maternal deaths), followed by toxemia (21 percent), hemorrhage (16 percent) and sepsis (11 percent).2 2.3 The high maternal mortality and morbidity rates are a direct result of insufficient and poor quality prenatal and delivery care, and family planning services. Poorly performed deliveries also account for an important share of infant deaths as birth lesions are by far the main cause of death of children under one year of age. Only two-thirds of all Paraguayan births are delivered by professional medical staff (physicians and nurse- midwives). Close to half of all births are home births. Only countries with sizeable indigenous populations such as Bolivia, Peruz and Guatemala have lower coverage. Moreover, the coverage of institutional births has not improved in the last decade.3 In the northem departments, the focus of this project, coverage of professionally attended deliveries was only 42 percent in 1990, and close to three-quarters of deliveries were home births. The poor and rural population rely heavily on the services of midwives. Considering that access to safe water is minimal in poor rural households, home births are likely to be more risky. It also increases the likelihood of stunted mental development. The most rapid mental growth occurs during infancy and early childhood. Inadequate intellectual stimulation and affective care combined with malnutrition are likely to result in irreversible damage to a child's physical and mental development.8 Early child stimulation programs targeting infants and toddlers and pre-school programs can improve school readiness skills. Other benefits include: the lowering of primary school enrollment ages, reduction of repetition and dropout rates, and improvement in academic performance. Parental involvement in programs also appears to strengthen the positive impact of early childhood interventions. 2.10 Pre-schools are scarce in Paraguay. Less than four percent of children six years of age and under are enrolled in pre-school. Other options for children are childcare centers ("guarderias" and "jardines infantiles"), the majority of which are privately owned and managed. The only pre-school program targeting low-income children is the Mita i Roga Program, established by the Ministry of Education and UNICEF in 1984. However, the program has been seriously weakened due to lack of funding which has severely restricted the training and supervision of its largely volunteer staff. Today, its coverage is insignificant. The Social Welfare Directorate (DGBS) of the MSPBS also targets low- income groups through its small network of community child care centers. However, child care centers provide no educational inputs for the children. Only seven of them have been specifically organized as child development centers where some early stimulation and food supplementation is provided. Originally, the DGBS covered all installation and operating costs. In the past two years, the DGBS has been developing a strategy to get communities to cover operating costs and some installation costs. 2.11 Given the increasing participation of mothers in the labor force, demand for child care options has increased in recent years, particularly in urban areas. Twenty percent of all women are in the formal labor force. The proportion of women employed in the informal sector is also likely to be sizable, particularly among the poor. Since poor mothers have less purchasing power to obtain either child care or pre-school education for their children, access to child development centers would improve children's welfare directly through early stimulation programs, and indirectly by allowing the mother to work and be able to better contribute to her children's education. 8 This discussion is drawn from "Investing in Young Children" by E.M.Young, World Bank Discussion Paper No. 275, 1995.
 8 B. STRUCTURE OF THE HEALTH SECTOR 2.12 Sector Organization and Coverage. Health care in Paraguay is provided by the Ministry of Public Health and Social Welfare (Ministerio de Salud Publica y Bienestar Social, MSPBS), the Institute of Social Security (Instituto de Previsi6n Social, IPS), the Police Health Service (Sanidad Policial, SP), the Armed Forces Health Service (Sanidad Militar, SM), and through the four University teaching hospitals, two of them belonging to the University of Asunci6n (Hospital de Clinicas (HC) and the Neuropsychiatric Hospital) and two affiliated with the Catholic University. The MSPBS provides both curative and preventive care,9 with an emphasis on the former. The rest of the public sector provides only curative care. The HC is a highly specialized tertiary care facility which accepts referrals from all institutions. Private health care is provided by hospitals, clinics, and laboratories, some of which function through various private insurance systems, and by various NGOs with limited coverage. The Mennonites also provide some hospital and clinic care, and the Pastoral Social (formerly Caritas) provides some primary health care at the community level. NGOs and the Pastoral Social provide primarily preventive care. In addition, care is provided informally by pharmacies, midwives and traditional healers. 2.13 The MSPBS is responsible for the health needs of the Paraguayan population, focusing its efforts on those not covered by other institutions, namely low income households.  10 3. KEY SECTOR ISSUES 3.1 Public health care in Paraguay has been characterized by an inadequate allocation of resources and a weak and technically inefficient delivery system. Both translate into an inequitable coverage of services to the detriment of more remote and poor populations, and to generally low quality services. The limited emphasis on prevention has led to a concentration of resources away from some of the more cost-effective interventions. Weak management and limited policy analysis and formulation capability, both at central and more peripheral levels (Departments and Municipalities), are likely to restrain even further the opportune and efficient delivery of services. 3.2 The main weaknesses of the Paraguayan health system can be grouped into three closely linked issues: equity, quality and efficiency. A. EQUITY 3.3 Lack of Access to Health Resources. Health infrastructure and resources are unevenly distributed. Tertiary care is concentrated in and around Asunci6n'3 and other urban areas. Seventy percent of tertiary care facilities are located in Asunci6n and the surrounding areas, and only 4 percent in the northern and eastern departments which contain 30 percent of the population. Secondary and primary care facilities are more evenly distributed. However, pharmaceuticals and medical supplies and equipment are often scarce at lower levels of care. Thus, the rural population has limited access to tertiary health care, and access only to resource-poor facilities at the secondary and primary levels. Obstetric complications, an important cause of maternal morbidity and mortality, cannot be appropriately cared for in rural facilities, and due to staff shortages, also fail to be resolved in many secondary level facilities. 3.4 The lack of basic infrastructure and limited purchasing power of the population has also discouraged private providers from establishing services in many areas. Although both the IPS and SM have health centers outside Asunci6n, they are fewer in number, and only accept individuals covered by social security (in the case of IPS) and members of the military (in the case of SM). Outside Asunci6n, the only providers serving the poor are the MSPBS, traditional community providers (midwives and healers), and religious organizations such as Pastoral Social and the Mennonites. Moreover, given the emphasis on curative care, available services have only a limited capacity to improve reproductive and child health. 3.5 Even when facilities are available, their location is not always appropriate, making it difficult for a system of referrals and distribution of supplies to work properly. Roads are often unpaved and impassable during the rainy season, and river transportation is slow 13 Three of the most highly specialized hospitals (Hospital Nacional, Hospital del Quemado, and Hospital de Cancer) are located in Central Department, a few miles from the center of Asunci6n).
 11 and infrequent. The poor and inefficient communications system aggravates the problem even further. Posts and centers lack radios and telephones. Regional hospitals possess only one or two telephone lines. Staff in health posts have bicycles or motorcycles, but often work alone and cannot leave the post. Thus, access to some remote populations can be severely restricted. 3.6 Given existing infrastructure maldistribution and deficiencies, poor communications and lack of amenities, health personnel have few incentives to work in resource-poor regions. Precise figures regarding the distribution of health personnel are difficult to obtain because many hold more than one post, and can be registered as working in one department when they in fact work in another (usually Asunci6n). Available figures indicate that most physicians, including the medical staff of the MSPBS, are located in Asunci6n and Central, as are licensed nurses and auxiliary nurses. The northern departments have the largest deficit of health personnel. 3.7 Unequal Distribution of the Burden of Disease. The unequal access to health resources has contributed to higher morbidity and mortality in the more remote departments and rural areas in general, than in Asunci6n and its environs. Infant mortality rates are three times higher in Alto Paraguay than in Asunci6n. The same is true for maternal mortality. B. QUALITY 3.8 The deficient quality of care is reflected in low occupancy and utilization rates. Many of the elements that determine quality of services need to be strengthened in Paraguay. Among the more important dimensions of quality are: technical competence, client/provider relations, timely availability of inputs (human resources, pharmaceuticals, and supplies) and adequate service infrastructure. Quality deteriorates with the level of care. Primary care lacks the most inputs. Posts lack the needed pharmaceuticals, are inadequately staffed, and equipment is often lacking or malfunctioning. The limited capability of the lower levels of care to resolve many of the cases they receive has broken down the referral system and has forced patients to go directly to the regional hospitals or to Asunci6n. 3.9 Weak Service Delivery Infrastructure. Health infrastructure, even in the case of some recently constructed facilities, is in an advanced state of deterioration. Some infrastructure is very old and outdated. In other cases, including recent construction, the building materials employed have been of substandard quality, leading to rapid decay. However, the most important reason for the deteriorated state of infrastructure has to do with a lack of maintenance of existing facilities. Health facilities are given a very small budget for maintenance, and the needed funds are partially covered by a sometimes unstable source, i.e., royalties from the Itaipu hydroelectric dam. Construction, even when in an acceptable physical state, is often designed without adequate functional planning, particularly when renovations are made to existing facilities, causing some of the existing infrastructure to be less effectively used.
 12 3.10 Equipment, both medical and non-medical, is also deteriorated and outdated. Medical equipment and instruments are often lacking due to insufficient resources. As in the case of infrastructure, equipment maintenance has not been a priority in the past. Staff employing the equipment often lack the training to do so, leading to a greater rate of malfunction than would otherwise be expected. A lack of inventory and control of equipment has resulted in significant losses. 3.11 Availability and Timeliness of Inputs. Health facilities, particularly health centers and posts, often lack some basic medical supplies and pharmaceuticals. Patients have to purchase supplies and medications in local pharmacies to receive treatment at centers and posts. The current pharmaceutical supply system is administratively cumbersome and exceedingly slow. Although regional facilities make periodic requests for pharmaceuticals needed, they often receive neither the amount nor the products requested. Moreover, budget allocations for pharmaceuticals and supplies are insufficient and favor hospitals, leaving centers and posts with minimal supplies. Part of the problem stems from the fact that, as is the case with funds for infrastructure maintenance, royalties from the Itaipui hydro-electric dam have been employed to finance these items. And, the "social pharmacies" established with revolving funds in each regional hospital to provide the population with lower-cost pharmaceuticals several years ago have failed to replenish their stocks because of inadequate inventory control. A lack of needed pharmaceuticals and supplies at facilities can severely reduce effectiveness of treatment of emergencies. 3.12 Also lacking, particularly at the more peripheral levels, are physicians. Many centers are understaffed and even when physicians are available, they generally work only a few hours before going to their private practice. 3.13 Provider Technical Competence. Components of the service delivery system designed to ensure the proper functioning of "hardware" inputs are also weak. Supervision of services is minimal, normative standards are sometimes inadequate and often not observed, training is limited and inappropriate, and management skills of administrative staff are insufficient. Supervision of posts and centers takes place only two or three times per year, and is generally limited to the collection of service statistics and the delivery of goods. Auxiliary nurses, who are required to have a minimum of primary school education (but in practice often do not), receive only nine months of training prior to their employment as nurse's aides. Licensed nurses do receive four years of college level training, but are few in number. Funding for training has been scarce, and often personnel shortages do not permit existing staff to take the time to attend training sessions. Moreover, the training methodology employed is inadequate. Courses have a theoretical rather than practical orientation, with training materials often having a limited bearing on the functions staff are expected to perform. 3.14 Client-Provider Relations. The human dimension of service delivery, i.e., the quality of interactions between health staff and the client, is also deficient. Complaints about poor attitudes towards patients are common. Providers also fail to communicate important health information to clients during clinic visits, leaving patients with little understanding of how to deal with their ailments.
 13 C. TECHNICAL AND ALLOCATIVE EFFICIENCY 3.15 Insufficient Emphasis on Preventive Care. Curative care absorbs most of the MSPBS' budget. As a result, many important preventive activities fall short of needs. The emphasis on family planning is also insufficient. Despite the high levels of maternal mortality and morbidity derived from complications of induced abortion, few women receive any guidance regarding contraception while hospitalized. Health centers and regional hospitals attend two women with complications of induced abortion for every birth they deliver. Treatment of complications of induced abortion are high in comparison to the costs of providing family planning services. The Government has relied completely on foreign aid to satisfy this need and thus does not budget funds for contraceptives. Contraceptive supplies are often lacking, and services and information are provided only two or three mornings per week. Family planning counseling is not provided on a regular basis, nor are high risk groups such as women under 20 years of age targeted. Basic training of health personnel only recently began to include training on reproductive health. 3.16 Health education is not one of the priorities of center and post staff. Health facilities lack educational materials for clients, and no structured health education sessions are held. The only opportunity to transmit health information to patients is during clinic visits, and few health staff take advantage of this opportunity to inform and educate patients. Growth monitoring is not consistently performed. Community outreach is rare, as health post staff are unable to leave their post due to a shortage of staff In 1990 (ends 1991), only about 50 percent of all children received the needed dosages of measles, polio and DPT vaccination, and only 40 percent received it in the North. Only one-third of all children receive all vaccinations. Tetanus toxoid immunization coverage is higher with two-thirds of women sampled having received full tetanus immunization during their last pregnancy. 3.17 One of the few programs that does focus on prevention is the child development program of the DGBS. As part of its effort to address the mental and physical health of children under 5 years of age, the DGBS has established community centers (Centros de Bienestar de la Infancia y la Familia, CEBINFA) providing early childhood stimulation, food supplementation, and facilitating access to health services. They also provide training in childcare for caretaking mothers. However, the centers are few in number, and educational activities do not focus sufficiently on health and nutrition education for mothers. 3.18 Weak Management Capability. Management skills are deficient at all levels, and are most deficient at peripheral levels. The MSPBS lacks the information required to make rational resource allocation decisions. Many staff also lack the necessary training to employ available information for policy and resource allocation purposes. In addition to facing the same lack of inputs, regional managers also have had less experience in making allocative decisions. Because all decision-making has been very centralized in the past, they have had few incentives to improve their management skills.

The loan funds will finance civil works, goods, consultant's services, maintenance of equipment and infrastructure, and some operational costs. Procurement procedures to be established for this project will follow the Bank's Guidelines (January 1995, as revised in 1996). During appraisal the Bank carried out a detailed review of procedures and documents in use in Paraguay. Some discrepancies between Bank and local procurement practices were identified in a review conducted in 1992 by the Bank. These have been resolved by using standard documents, and ensuring that the Loan Agreements contain specific mention of each item for the procurement of civil works, goods and/or consulting services (see Annex 6 for specific procurement provisions for Paraguay). 8.2 The project design nrovides for a combination of centralized and decentralized implementation mechanisms. Most drugs and medical supplies, some of the goods (namely medical equipment), and most technical assistance will be procured centrally by the PCU. Civil works and some goods and consulting services will be procured by each of the RCOs at the regional level through NCB, international and national shopping. RCOs would be monitored and audited by the PCU. In the case of health regions having limited procurement capability, the PCU (the Coordinator for Investments and the Procurement Specialist) will provide administrative and technical support to the RCOs and facilities to procure those works, goods and services centrally, but with representation from the health regions in all procedures, both to train local staff and to ensure local needs are taken into account. In the case of civil works, the RCO and relevant regional staff will prepare, with technical assistance from the PCU, the technical documentation (technical specifications and draft bidding documents). The Coordinator for Investments has received training on Bank procurement procedures and has ample experience in procurement for civil works and medical equipment. RCO Coordinators will receive ample training on procurement for civil works including procedural and technical aspects. The Operational Manual will contain a detailed description of the procedures to be followed at every step. 8.3 Bid evaluation commissions for decentralized procurement will include the regional director, the facility director, a representative of the Regional Health Council (the Health Secretary), the RCO, and a representative from the bidding department of the central MSPBS. In the case of centralized procurement, as will be the case with the purchase of pharmaceuticals and most medical equipment, the PCU will ensure that the health regions involved have majority representation in the bidding commissions and that they have participation in the preparation of the technical specifications of the bidding documents. Bid evaluation commissions for centralized procurement will include the regional director, a representative of the Regional Health Council (the Health Secretary), and the RCO for each of the regions involved in the particular bidding process, a

The civil works to be carried out involve the rehabilitation of health centers and regional hospitals in six health regions and the rehabilitation of CEBINFAs in Asunci6n. The total estimated cost of the civil works component is about US$6.0 million (Table 7), out of which approximately US$5.2 million equivalent (or 86 percent of the total cost) will be financed by the Bank. Civil works contracts will be awarded on the basis of National Competitive Bidding (NCB), with the average contract estimated at US$120,000 equivalent and none expected to exceed US$200,000. B. INSTITUTIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES AND IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 9.3 Institutional Responsibilities. The executing agency for the proposed project is the MSPBS through a project coordination unit (PCU) reporting directly to the Minister and the General Directorate of Projects with International Cooperation (OPCI). The PCU
 44 will coordinate directly with the General Directorates within the Ministry and the Regional Directorates. Each Regional Directorate will have a Regional Coordination Office (RCO) staffed with one regional project coordinator with a professional profile, functions and responsibilities as established in Annex 7, satisfactory to the Bank. Each region would be allocated a specific budget for project implementation depending on needs determined in the annual implementation plan. The health region's use of project funds will be accountable to the MSPBS. 9.5 Project Administration. The project would be administered by the PCU and RCOs in the participating health regions. In addition to the Project Director, the PCU will have 3 coordinators who would divide responsibilities as follows: (a) administration- finances; (b) civil works, equipment, and maintenance; and (c) training, IEC, management support and early child development. Procurement of pharmaceuticals would be carried out by the Procurement Specialist under the supervision of the Technical Coordinator. Each of these coordinators would be supported by two or three assistants. RCO coordinators would be supported by one assistant. A diagram of the structure of the PCU and the profile and functions of the four key positions within the PCU and the coordinators for the RCOs are contained in Annex 7. The PCU is in charge of overall coordination, planning, logistical support and supervision of the project, ensuring execution is carried out in accordance with established guidelines, procedures and targets. Together with the RCOs, it will also provide technical assistance to regional staff in the preparation of bidding documents and annual investment plans (including infrastructure, equipment and training). The RCOs will also be actively involved in the supervision of project activities at the local level. 9.6 The Operational Manual sets forth the functions and structure of the PCU, TORs for the director, the three key PCU positions and for the regional coordinators, administrative and financial procedures, procurement arrangements and plans, and reporting and auditing requirements. In order to build project management capacity early on, it was agreed that a project director would be selected and contracted prior to negotiations, and that the selection and hiring of the three key coordinators would be a condition of loan effectiveness. EXPECTED PROJECT BENEFITS 13.1 The main medium-term benefit of the project would be the improvement of the health of women and children in project areas through direct interventions designed to improve the quality and quantity of care provided and through an increased emphasis on preventive care in MSPBS services. Other benefits include: (a) an increase in the

B. ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 13.2 Paraguay's cause of death structure characterizes it as being in a mid- epidemiological transition stage, with both infectious diseases and chronic/degenerative diseases being among the top five killers. Infectious diseases, including upper respiratory tract infections and diarrheal disease, are included among the main causes of death of the population as a whole, along with cardiovascular disease, neoplasms and accidents. Death from perinatal causes (birth lesions, infections and neonatal tetanus) is also significant. And, maternal mortality is the highest in the region. Infectious diseases, perinatal and maternal death are all characteristic of contexts with high fertility (young population) and poor health delivery capability. And, all are amenable to effective, low-cost interventions with short-term results. Institutional interventions designed to improve the quality and coverage of prenatal and delivery care, child immunization, and family planning services, combined with individual household level interventions designed to improve health practices in the home and the community can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality due to the above mentioned causes. Although inducing behavior change is sometimes more costly than a highly specific and effective interventions such as immunization, it is a necessary element of long-term, sustainable change. While the health of the population can be also be enhanced through improvements in overall educational attainment, socio- economic development, and the environment, they are more costly interventions and have a less immediate effect. 13.3 Many activities financed under the proposed project do not lend themselves to quantitative economic analysis. And, those that would in other circumstances, are difficult to measure because of the dearth of reliable Paraguayan data on health indicators, service availability and quality, health expenditures and costs. However, the cost-effectiveness of most of the interventions to be financed by the project has been quantified in many other contexts. Prenatal and delivery care, and family planning, for example, have been shown to be highly cost-effective in other countries. According to the findings of the 1993 World Development Report, Investing in Health, the annual cost per participant of prenatal and delivery care in low income countries is US$90. The annual cost per user of family planning services is US$12. Child health interventions were estimated to cost US$9 per participant and treatment of minor trauma for all ages up to US$6 per participant. Thus, the annual cost per participant for this package of services comes to US$117 per user. This same package, including health education, which was not costed per participant, is
 50 estimated to cost US$12 per capita. The estimated per capita cost of providing these services within the Project comes to US$8.70, well below the estimated average. Costs are low given the reliance on health care personnel other than doctors (nurses and community health workers, such as midwives), who are less expensive. 13.4 In addition to employing cost.effective interventions, the project will significantly reduce the current costs of deliveiing services by reducing the incidence of complications of induced abortion. Fertility in Paraguay, at 4.7 births per woman, is the second highest in South America. Judging by the levels of induced abortion, the most important cause of maternal mortality, uLnwanted fertility is also high. Family planning services can significantly reduce unwanted fertility and therefore induced abortion and its complications. Family planning services, particularly when delivered through community- based distribution (as in the case of this; project), are the most cost-effective means of reducing maternal mortality, and improving maternal and child health. Using the average costs of treatment of abortion-related complications derived from elsewhere in Latin America (an average of $400 per abortion), this implies a cost to the health system of at least US$480,000 dollars per year for the project areas alone24. Family planning services can cost as little as US$20 per user per year. 13.5 The success of project interventions in meeting project objectives will be carefully measured during the last year of the project. Pregnant women will receive two tetanus toxoid immunizations during pregnancy and a three-month supply of iron, micronutrient, and vitamin supplementation in each visit. Midwives will evaluate the obstetric risk of pregnant women coming for prenatal care and refer high risk women to health centers. Delivery Care Low risk deliveries will be performed at lower levels of care, reserving the space at regional hospitals for high risk pregnancies. Only health posts with auxiliaries in obstetrics will perform deliveries. Should a complication arise during delivery at a health center or post, the patient will be transferred to a regional hospital through health service transportation when available, or community-organized transportation. Only health posts staffed with an auxiliary specialized in obstetrics will provide delivery care. The baby's weight, height and Apgar score will be measured. Health education to be provided will include information on breastfeeding and
 58 Annex 2 infant care. Midwives will perform deliveries in the community, as they always have, but with further training and backup transportation in cases of emergency. They will also provide information on breastfeeding and infant care. Midwives and health post staff will register infants for growth monitoring. A pilot will be conducted to assess the feasibility and benefits of having midwives perform deliveries in health posts which have no auxiliary specialized in obstetrics. Postpartum Care Postpartum care will include, at all levels of care, a pelvic exam, and health education focusing on exclusive breastfeeding, appropriate weaning, infant care and family planning. CHWs and midwives in the community will reinforce health education provided at health facilities. Other Reproductive Health: Family Planning, Treatment of Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs) and Detection of Cervical Cancer Family planning information and services will be available at all levels of care, and to some extent in the community through midwives and CHWs. They will be instrumental in identifying non-users who belong to high-risk groups, such as adolescents, and providing them with information on reproductive health and, more specifically, on family planning. They will provide barrier methods to current and new users and resupply oral contraceptives to current users. A pilot will be conducted whereby midwives will be allowed to charge a nominal fee for contraceptives and keep it as payment for their work. Hormonal methods to new users will be prescribed at health facilities. Methods available at health posts include all non-clinical methods (barrier methods, and hormonals (except implants)). They will make referrals to other levels of care for other methods. Health centers will provide non-clinical methods and IUD insertion, where staff are trained to do so, and will make referrals for other clinical methods. Regional hospitals will provide surgical, clinical and non-clinical methods. Community workers will also address some basic reproductive health issues in their educational efforts including STDs and cervical cancer. All levels of the health care network will provide STD screening. However, treatment will only be available at centers and regional hospitals. STD screening will be performed during prenatal examinations or general gynecological checkups. Health posts will employ simple, inexpensive diagnostic techniques (pH dipsticks, and potassium hydroxide and normal saline). Health centers with laboratory facilities and regional hospitals will provide more sophisticated screening procedures and will provide treatment. Pap smears will also be available at health centers with laboratory facilities and regional hospitals for women over 35 years of age. Positive test results will be followed up by facility staff. Child Health Preventive child care services will be provided at health posts and in the community through midwives and CHWs. They will be responsible for the identification of malnourished and ill children in the community and make referrals to health facilities. In coordination with health post and center staff, organize immunization campaigns. CHWs will provide health education for mothers on oral rehydration therapy (ORT), child care, hygiene and nutrition. Growth monitoring

 78 Annex 10 ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. Introduction This annex provides a detailed justification for the project. It consolidates material discussed in various sections of this report in order to address, step by step, the relevant issues and considerations that led to the present project design. The analysis considers: (a) linkages to economic and sector work; (b) analysis of alternatives; and (c) impact and sustainability. The primary objective of the proposed project is to improve maternal and child health in six predominantly rural departments in northeastern Paraguay. This region of the country contains most of the recent migrant settlements and a majority of indigenous population. The six departments have limited access to running water, sewage disposal and electricity. With the exception of four departments in the Chaco, which together contain less than two percent of the population, five of the departments included in the project have the highest poverty levels in Paraguay. The total poor population to be covered by the health component is approximately 500,000, out of which 210,000 are children under five years of age and women of childbearing age. Maternal and child mortality and morbidity in these departments are among the highest in the nation. B. Linkages to Economic and Sector Work Resuming operations in 1990, after a long hiatus, the Bank conducted a number of studies to update its knowledge-base of the Paraguayan economy and current economic and social conditions. A Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) was developed on the basis of the results of the initial economic and sector studies'. The CAS was discussed and approved by the Board of Executive Directors on December 21, 1993 with the Eighth Highways Project (Report P-5916-PA). Country Assistance Strategy. The objectives of the Bank's assistance strategy in Paraguay are to support: (a) private sector development; (b) agricultural development and natural resource management; and (c) poverty alleviation through human resource development. The CAS specifically identifies the improvement of social service delivery as a priority to alleviate poverty and strengthen human resources. It notes the importance of improving the targeting of health services, service quality, and resource allocation within the sector. Maternal and child morbi-mortality were identified as unnecessarily high given that they can be easily prevented. The need to strengthen institutional capacity, particularly in the areas of investment and budget planning, management, accounting and 'Country Economic Memorandum - CEM (Report No. 9147-PA dated October 15, 1991), Public Expenditure Review: The Social Sectors (Report No. 10193-PA dated June 16, 1992),and a study of the implications of Paraguay's joining the MERCOSUR trade area (Report No. 10902-PA dated January 28, 1993).
 79 Annex 10 control, and other measures to increase administrative efficiency was stressed. The strengthening of management capability at all levels was highlighted, in light of the decentralization and deconcentration of social services that is beginning to take place. Economic and Sector Work (ESW). Early sector work shaped the content of the CAS. The analysis noted that public health resources are poorly allocated, with most health expenditures being absorbed by salaries (up to 80 percent). It also noted that public resources are concentrated on curative rather than preventive care, and on tertiary care over the lower levels of care. A report completed after the CAS was drafted, focused specifically on the poverty and the social sectors (Poverty and the Social Sectors in Paraguay, Report No. 12293-PA, dated June 29, 1994). This report showed the poor to be located principally in the periphery of Asunci6n, the northern departments and part of the East. It found that the poor are more likely to have limited schooling and poor health, and that they are more likely to be indigenous and migrants. In its examination of the relationship between health and poverty, the report indicated that health resources are unevenly distributed, resulting in an overconcentration of resources in Asunci6n and other large urban areas at the expense of poorer regions. This maldistribution has resulted in significantly higher rates of maternal and child morbidity and mortality in these departments. Sector work also noted the important role that community participation has had in social development projects and recommends its incorporation into projects. The Project. The proposed project fully supports the country assistance strategy and findings of the ESW. The main objective of the project is to improve maternal and child health in project areas through direct interventions designed to: (a) improve available infrastructure and equipment; (b) improve competence of MSPBS paramedical staff through a modified and enhanced training methodology; (c) increase general awareness and information regarding health promotion and good health behavior among the population; (d) increase the emphasis on preventive health in MSPBS services; (e) facilitate access to less expensive pharmaceuticals; (f) improve regional management and implementation capability; (g) increase access of early stimulation programs for poor urban children; (h) increase child care options for low-income mothers, and (i) strengthen collaboration with the community and NGOs to improve service delivery. The project also seeks to enhance early child development through a small pilot designed to establish integrated child development centers. The project's integrated child development activities would also improve working opportunities for women. The health component would target six of the poorest departments in Paraguay. The child development component would target the urban fringes of Asunci6n, another area of high incidence of poverty identified by the poverty report. C. Analysis of Alternatives Why a Health Care Intervention? Several avenues are available to improve the health of the population. Health can be enhanced through improvements in educational attainment, socio-economic development, individual life-styles and the environment as
 80 Annex 10 much as it can be by the health care system itself The greater the importance of communicable diseases in the overall burden of disease, the greater the potential impact of health care improvements. The more chronic and degenerative disease in a population, i.e. the older the population, the greater the role of economic development, education, life- styles and the environment in improving health. In Paraguay, communicable diseases are important contributors to the burden of disease. Thus, direct interventions in how services are delivered will have an important effect on health status. Also, the Bank is already financing a secondary education project, a rural water supply project, and, in Asunci6n, a sewerage project. Why Maternal and Child Health? Paraguay's cause of death structure characterizes it as being in a mid-epidemiological transition stage, with both infectious diseases and chronic/degenerative diseases being among the top five killers. Infectious diseases, including upper respiratory tract infections and diarrheal disease are included among the main causes of death of the population as a whole, along with cardiovascular disease, neoplasms and accidents. Death from perinatal causes (birth lesions, infections and neonatal tetanus) is also significant. And, maternal mortality is the highest in the region. Infectious diseases, perinatal and maternal death are all characteristic of contexts with high fertility (young population) and poor health delivery capability. And, are all amenable to effective, low cost interventions with short-term effects. Cardiovascular disease and neoplasms are more typical of a low fertility (older) population, and accidents are more common in more urbanized settings. Reducing mortality from these causes is considerably more expensive, and prevention is very long-term. Investing in maternal and child health will have longer term effects as children have a whole life ahead of them (cardiovascular disease and neoplasms affect older generations), and shorter-term results, and tackling them will be considerably less costly. It may be argued that in order for the MSPBS to make sustainable changes in the quality and coverage of health services, projects would need to address the manner in which health care is financed, how resources are allocated within the sector, and how allocated resources are used. It would require a careful analysis of how the system functions and of the feasible alternatives to guide change. ESW has not focused on the health sector and thus little is known regarding health financing, sector efficiency and effectiveness, and equity. Little is known of the extent of private sector delivery and finance, and how it is regulated. There is no information on the quality of private services, nor of the coverage of private health insurance. What is known is that not enough resources are spent on health, and that 80 percent are absorbed by salaries, leaving managers little room to "allocate" resources. Moreover, given the Government's intention to decentralize the health sector, the current paradigm could change significantly. A project designed to introduce some structural changes would require a detailed analysis of the sector and a clear view as to which way the decentralization is headed. The proposed project seeks to reduce the ill-effects of the maldistribution of resources on the poor, and will, to the extent possible, correct some of the allocation problems. By investing in secondary level facilities it reduces the tertiary care bias, and by
 81 Annex 10 investing in preventive care it reduces the curative care bias. Moreover, the project will finance activities to improve the management of health services at the regional and central levels to ensure more effective decision-making at least regarding project inputs. The project's objectives, to reduce maternal and child morbidity and mortality, are in line with the Bank's assistance strategy for Paraguay and the GOP's health priorities. In response to the poor state of maternal and perinatal health, the Government drafted a National Plan for the Reduction of Maternal and Perinatal Mortality in 1994, to be implemented in conjunction with other public and private providers with both local and external funding. Why this Project Design? The main causes of maternal death in Paraguay are abortion, toxemia, hemorrhage, and sepsis. The high maternal mortality and morbidity rates are a direct result of a lack of appropriate prenatal care, unsafe delivery care, and absence of family planning services. In project, areas one-half of all birth are delivered by midwives, many of which work in unsanitary settings and are improperly trained. Poorly performed births account for an important share of infant deaths as birth lesions are by far the main cause of death of children under one year of age. Inadequate access to modern2 contraceptive services and information accounts for the high proportion of women bearing children in situations that are more likely to result in pregnancy and birth complications (i.e. bearing children when they are too young, too old, of high parity or within short birth intervals) and a high level of unwanted fertility (as evidenced by the high number of induced abortions). One third of women giving birth in Paraguay can be classified as being of high reproductive risk. Besides reducing the mother's risk of infection and other complications, safe delivery will reduce the incidence of birth lesions, sepsis and asphyxia in newborns. Family planning has beneficial effects both for the mother and for the survival of her child as well. Family planning reduces maternal mortality by reducing the risk of induced abortion, and by reducing exposure to childbirth complications. Family planning also helps women lengthen the interval between births allowing them to recover fully between births, and in this way increasing the chances of survival of their newborn. The health service delivery interventions to be provided in project areas will be complemented by an information, education and communications program aimed at generating health promotion behavior at the household level. The information/education will be provided massively through a radio campaign and individually in health facilities and the community. Inducing behavior change leading to improved health practices will facilitate and enhance the effects of service delivery system interventions. The effects of health education are more difficult to measure but it has been widely demonstrated that health education leads to a more effective utilization of health care and to lower levels of morbidity of easily preventable causes. The cost per "illness" averted varies by type of morbidity. 2 Modern contraception includes any of the following methods: hormonal methods (orals, injections, or implants), intra-uterine devices, male and female sterilization, and barrier methods (condoms, foams, diaphragms, etc.).
 82 Annex 10 Improved prenatal care, safe delivery and family planning are the three main interventions designed to reduce maternal morbi-mortality in the project. All three have been shown to be highly cost-effective in other countries, particularly when combined with health education, as is the case in the proposed project. According to the findings of the 1993 World Development Report, Investing in Health, the annual cost per participant of prenatal and delivery care in low-income countries would be US$90. The annual cost per user of family planning services is US$12. The total cost per participant of prenatal, delivery and family planning services would come to US$102 in low-income countries. The main causes of infant deaths, i.e., birth lesions, tetanus and infections of the newborn, can all be easily prevented with adequate prenatal and delivery care. These causes account for one-third of all infant deaths. Other important causes of death among children under 5 years of age are acute respiratory infections (ARI) and diarrhea (accounting for one-quarter of all deaths), both preventable with adequate treatment, improved nutrition, adequate breastfeeding and weaning practices, access to safe water and health education. Thus, improved prenatal and delivery care and access to family planning services would reduce maternal and child mortality and morbidity significantly. Complementing these services with treatment of common infectious diseases children are vulnerable to and health education would address most of the health problems of these target groups. Among children under 5 years of age, one quarter of all deaths are due to acute respiratory infections (ARI) and diarrhea, both preventable with adequate treatment, improved nutrition, adequate breastfeeding and weaning practices, access to safe water and health education. These interventions are also very cost-effective. Treatment of common childhood illnesses comes to US$9 per participant, and treatment of minor trauma for all ages up to US$6 per participant according to the 1993 World Development Report. The 1993 World Development Report estimates the annual cost per participant to receive a package of services equivalent to what will be delivered under the project at US$117 per user. The per capita annual cost of providing this package of services (including health education, which was not costed per participant) comes to US$12. The estimated per capita cost of providing these services within the Project will come to US$8.70, well below the estimated average. Costs are low given the reliance on health care personnel other than doctors (nurses and community health workers, such as midwives), who are less expensive. In addition to employing cost-effective interventions, the project will significantly reduce the current costs of delivering services by reducing the incidence of complications of induced abortion. Fertility in Paraguay, at 4.7 births per woman, is the second highest in South America. Judging by the levels of induced abortion, the most important cause of maternal mortality, unwanted fertility is also high. Family planning services can significantly reduce unwanted fertility and therefore induced abortion and its complications. Family planning services, particularly when delivered through community- based distribution (as in the case of this project), are the most cost-effective means of reducing maternal mortality, and improving maternal and child health. Using the average
 83 Annex 10 costs of treatment of abortion-related complications derived from elsewhere in Latin America (an average of $400 per abortion), this implies a cost to the health system of at least $600,000 dollars a year for the project areas alone3. Family planning services can cost as little as US$20 per user per year. The success of project interventions in meeting project objectives will be carefully measured during the last year of the project. Given the poor quality of vital statistics and service delivery data, project impact will be measured by means of baseline and endline surveys in project areas. The Centers for Disease Control conducted a large-scale national maternal and child health household survey in January of 1996 which will be employed as baseline information. The same questionnaire will be applied in project areas during the final year of project implementation. Given the five-year interval, some mortality indicators can be measured, namely, child, infant and perinatal mortality. Some morbidity indicators are also available including prevalence of diarrhea, acute respiratory infection, and reproductive morbidity. In addition, indicators of coverage of professionally attended delivery, prenatal care, tetanus toxoid immunization, family planning, child immunization, are available as are service quality and utilization measures. The survey will also measure population information regarding the benefits of these services and will identify the source of that information. D. Financial and Fiscal Impact The Government of Paraguay invests relatively little in health. Including social security health services, the Government of Paraguay (GOP) spent less than 2.5 percent of GDP on health in 1994. What the Government does spend on health is also poorly allocated. It is estimated that salaries absorb 80-85 percent of public health expenditures. This means that there are insufficient resources to cover maintenance of facilities and equipment, to procure pharmaceuticals, medical supplies, and to train staff The sus.ainability of project investments has been a concern from the inception of the project. As a result, project design sought to optimize unit costs through: (a) an expansion of maternal and child health care which relies on existing health personnel and the incorporation of community midwives and health workers who deliver services relatively cheaply compared to doctors; (b) using the results of a study of the network and referral system for health facilities to guide the allocations for infrastructure rehabilitation in order to ensure that investments are channeled to the facilities most used by the population; (c) rehabilitating existing infrastructure instead of investing in new construction; and (d) increasing the durability of investments by assigning greater emphasis to maintenance of infrastructure and equipment. Cost savings are expected, 3 Health regions report between 200 and 250 treatments of complications of induced abortion per year, yielding an average of 1200 to 1500 per year for the project areas. Underreporting of abortion and its complications is common and thus one can assume the actual figures to be considerably higher. The costs of US$400 for the treatment of complications of induced abortion were obtained from a detailed study conducted in Nicaragua.
 84 Annex 10 particularly in the area of pharmaceuticals through the use of international competitive bidding as local prices exceed international prices by a wide margin. The only salaries to be financed by the project are for a small number of staff to assist in project management and infrastructure maintenance. Thus the incremental annual recurrent expenditures required when the program is in full operation is likely to be small ($1.2 million) consisting mainly of consumables (drugs and supplies) and maintenance costs for the anticipated higher quality and level of service delivery. Not only does this represent less than 1 percent of the current budget of the MSPBS, but it should be easily absorbable given the potential cost savings resulting from the project's efforts to improve maintenance and to lower the cost of drugs. In addition, the Government would gradually take over more responsibility for recurrent costs over the life of the project given the decreasing rate of Bank financing. E. Risk Analysis The main project risks are associated with: (a) the weak implementation capacity of the Ministry at the central and regional level; (b) poor programming of counterpart and project resources; and (c) administrative difficulties and legal barriers that could slow project execution. The risks associated with implementation capacity are being minimized by limiting the scope of activities and phasing their implementation, employing a detailed Operational Manual specifying the implementation responsibilities, procedures and timing to guide implementation, and providing technical assistance and training for MSPBS central and regional staff. Programming of project resources will be improved through the development of clear guidelines and procedures regarding the timing and steps required to ensure timely access to project and counterpart funds. These arrangements will be reviewed with the Ministry of Finance, and will be included in the Operational Manual. Administrative delays would be reduced by ensuring PCU staff have ample training on Bank procedures. PCU staff have already attended procurement and disbursement seminars, and have visited other Bank projects. Additional training will be made available prior to project start-up. In addition, the Operational Manual details all steps to be taken with regard to procurement, disbursement, and Bank reporting. Finally, an Administrative and Procurement Review to be held in the second year of the project will allow an early analysis and solution to issues arising during implementation.

doc.abstracts: The main objective of the Maternal Health and Child Development Project is to improve the health status of the underserved Paraguayan population, particularly women and children. To achieve this objective, the project will: 1) increase the coverage, quality and efficiency of basic maternal and child health services in six underserved departments in Northeastern Paraguay; 2) increase the population's knowledge about adequate health practices; 3) pilot-test a strategy to enhance early child development in Asuncion; and 4) strengthen management capability in support of an eventual decentralization of a public health services in project areas. It is expected that the project will: (a) increase the coverage and quality of institutional deliveries; (b) improve the safety of home deliveries; (c) improve the detection, transport and treatment of obstetric complications; (d) improve access to reproductive health services and information; (e) improve immunization coverage; (f) reduce the incidence of acute respiratory infections and diarrheal disease; (g) improve children's schooling readiness; and (h) increase community involvement in both health and child development activities. The components of the project are as follows: 1) maternal and child health care, including: (i) rehabilitation and maintenance of infrastructure and equipment; (ii) pharmaceuticals and medical supplies; (iii) information, education and communication; and (iv) training; 2) early child development pilot; and 3) strengthening management for the decentralization of health services in project areas.
